{"doc":{"info":{"calaisRequestID":"e03e10ab-a9e9-ee45-146f-22d7a803be10","id":"http://id.opencalais.com/707on4HrBmaceixEINPgUA","docId":"http://d.opencalais.com/dochash-1/93447008-87dd-3fad-832d-2f160de3d88e","document":" ￼*\"]COVER ILLUSTRATION \u2014 JBY KIM LEVIS 4r 7 )<o 4\" ckjT\" TV\\1SD\u2019ivjfv/l C_ATtS 10k \\ ' 2- fCoicV bdd >C <2_YWF>, IAf GROUND *4.95 -\u2014 yM-y'c DEBORAH RANDALL THE SIN EATER b«^l<d DEBORAH RANDALL ^0^0 The^Sin Eafer u |<L 'V^c C./br'S rSf2.£- \"to *«. FtKlltt pfbc<z_c^ b>lor^> ■-tf 5i^ 'Deborah Randall's poems are astonishing. Sometimes I'm tempted to call her' a genius, although I'm sure she'd laugh at such bloated terminology, judging by her work, which is earthed, gutsy, fiery and sensual in its dealings with the basics of life and death. 'This is her first collection: there is the odd echo of Sylvia Plath, Dylan Thomas or George Mackay Brown, but the tactics and cunning could only be Deborah Randall's and the rhythms are her own. 'Her poems are often teasing in their slantwise approach, and she draws on the myth-kitty as and when it suits her purposes, but she plants surprises and her timing is exact. Hers is a deft and womanly art,-as-dtrect and disorientating as a ride on the Big Dipper' -<^SYLVIA KANTARIS olin ryw c \u2014 ---------- I \u2022Deborah Randall has a distinctive, sexybravado which gladdens the heart' -^CAROL ANN DUFFY, Guardian WHITER OF THE BLOODAXE BOOKS NATIONAL POETRY COMPETITION \\ I^ rvi^C S.f2_e. -to POETRY BOOK SOCIETY RECOMMENDATION ^ C A P S i WvvcOi oroo (vyV* TD V U \n￼THE SIN EATER \n￼My Favourite Sunday Old ladies in church hats remind me of giraffes, something about gravity slipping chins down necks always straining for the pulpit in wet-look straw and raw crimplene, a squabble in their throats and bosoms with the massive swank of rhinoceros. Old ladies in church hats remind me of lions, a suggestion of puffy blue heads on the prowl, or hyenas daubed round the mouth an expression of just having eaten a carcase. White old ladies and that great white hunter the vicar, on safari together, it was invariably the young and the weak he sniped for over the sepulchre as we lay between the pews and played dead. y favourite Sunday was the Sunday I never to go to church again until I became an old lady and wanted to be eighty per cent of the church congregation and my own salvation then I suppose would seem more imperative, could no longer be said to be synonymous with surviving. \n￼Other People Also Bum Wood He slides an eye brimful with the best about lovers, somewhere over my shoulder. I want to recall my hands getting toasted on his sensed flame which is so far real not gas with mock fall-out. I smell incendiary wood on him which gives me a crackle in unmentionable memorable places. Strangers only, meet in my eye as if it were a market-place where they auction the business of the day, or a pub yawning on New Year\u2019s morning. He\u2019s in my eye talking in an office sort of way not really really looking here but somewhere over my shoulder where a chosen lover ","docTitle":"","docDate":"2014-07-01 09:46:45.919"},"meta":{"contentType":"text/raw","emVer":"7.1.1103.5","langIdVer":"DefaultLangId","processingVer":"CalaisJob01","submissionDate":"2014-07-01
